course_title: Introduction to Philosophy: What is Philosophy?

learning_outcomes.description: Understand some of the central debates in philosophy (breadth and depth)
Demonstrate basic skills of effective thinking and communication (clarity, relevance, accuracy)
Conduct independent philosophical research and inquiry
Identify, analyse and evaluate arguments or points of view
Understand the role of philosophy in everyday life

assessments.task_description: Students discuss the set reading for the relevant week. Marks are credited for participation, which includes demonstration of reading the set text and contribution to a community of philosophical inquiry (see marking and criteria). Tutorials run during weeks 2-12 (with no tutorial in week 7) and are face-to-face. This is an in-person assessment not permitting use of AI.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description: Students will be presented with a case study or hypothetical based on the philosophers of weeks 2-4 (Plato, Boethius, Aquinas). Students are required to write a 300 word analysis of the case through the lens of one of the chosen philosophers, then evaluate using their own individual judgement and perspective. Further details are available on the Blackboard site under 'Assessment'. Assignments must be submitted via TurnItIn (on Blackboard); check that your submission has been received. AI is not to be used for writing or planning this Assessment.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: Students will be required to write a philosophical essay on a question from Part One of the course. Questions will be specified in the 'Essay 1 Task Sheet' on the Blackboard site under 'Assessment'. Word count (including discursive footnotes but excluding references and bibliography): 1100-1200 words. For this assignment you may use any recognised referencing style. Assignments must be submitted via TurnItIn (on Blackboard); check that your submission has been received. AI generation is not to be used for this Assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: Students will be required to write a philosophical essay on a question from Part Two of the course. Questions will be specified in the ‘Essay Task Sheet' on the Blackboard site under 'Assessment.' Word count (including discursive footnotes but excluding bibliography): 1200-1300 words. For this assignment you may use any recognised referencing style. Assignments must be submitted via TurnItIn (on Blackboard); check that your submission has been received. AI is not to be used for this Assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

10 x one hour tutorials

Choose one tutorial time from the options on Allocate+.
Tutorials will be held weeks 2-8, 10-12.
